attributes.comment:
My husband and I are in the process of adopting a baby girl from China. We
submitted our I-600A in Jan 2006 and received our I-171H in May 06. Our dossier
was logged in ("LID") to China 6/19/06. Due to lengthening referral times in China
(e.g. from 8-9 mos when we began this process, to current waiting time of 16-17
mos), we do not expect our referral until Oct/Nov 06. Since the 171-H expires in
18 mos, and must be valid when we travel to China to get our child, we will now
have to reapply to renew our I-171H and pay the entire I-600A application fee
again. We, and other parents pursuing international adoption, have no control over
the referral and travel waiting times, hence many families (especially for China) are
going to have to pay double I-600A fees. If docket # 2006-0044 goes into effect,
we will pay even higher fees in addition to repeat fees, and this is unacceptable.
This is yet another reason why the I-171H expiration should be extended to 24
months, and renewable without having to resubmit an I-600A and pay duplicate
fees (i.e. when nothing in our application has changed!).
Higher fees should not be charged to adoptive families, who are already paying
thousands of dollars to adopt children from foreign countries in order to provide
them with a family and a better life. I have read the docket 2006-0044 and totally
disagree with USCIS adoption form fees being increased to support the
Immigration Examination Fee Account to "provide services to asylum and refugee
applicants and certain other immigrants at no charge." In my opinion, those
applicants should have to pay the same fees as everyone one else applying for
citizenship- if they can't afford immigration fees, they should be able to apply for
citizenship, period. Adoptive families should not have to pay higher fees to
support immigrants who can't afford fees; this is another indication that
immigration into the U.S. needs to be better controlled and limited.
attributes.title: Comment Submitted by Julie Working
